history.content:
Essential Classes:

EE16AB

CS70

Math53

EE126

EE127

CS189

Math 110

Math 104

After taking these, there are various classes (both undergrad and graduate) that offer more specialization. These classes make up the foundation for a strong career in ML. Where you specialize beyond this is up to you. However, it is strongly recommend to take graduate level classes after these to deepen intuition.

=================

Just want to add some other choices

Course plan for industry:

EE16A + EE16B or Math 54 + EE16B

CS70

Math53

CS189

CS182

Alternative plan for people who focus on data and wants less workload:

EE16A + EE16B or Math 54 + EE16B

Math 53

CS70 + Prob140

Data 100

Reduced plan for ML/DL/Data research:

EE16A + EE16B or Math 54 + EE16B

Math 53

CS70 + EECS126

CS189

Hard Core ML research(Phd path):

EE16A + EE16B or Math 54 + EE16B

Math 110(requires 54) or EECS127(requires EE16AB)

CS70 + EE126

Math53 + Math 104 + Math 202A† (not sure about 202 but heard it is useful from researchers I know)

CS189

CS188*

Grad Classes

You didn't see 188 in most of the plans I posted, this is because

*CS188 depends on which subset of AI field you want to go to. Personally I found its contents only useful for Hard Core ML research, but many people in this category don't take it and just self-study 188's material quickly.

†(Footnote from other person:) Math 202A teaches measure theory, which serves as the foundation for a good general treatment of probability, but if your goal is just ML and therefore probability, then you might be better served by Stat 205 (crosslisted as Math 218), which is just a course in probability and covers the necessary measure theory at the beginning.

children.subject: I think they are overkill for industry. You will definitely learn 189 better by taking them and gain more mathematical maturity, but EE16A+EE16B are already specially structured to prepare you well for 189. Also, take CS182, much more important than 189 for industry. The above applies for ML developers, but for research positions in industries, seriously think about grad education.
But for anyone who do research, go take EE127 and EE126, even after taking 189.
Was 182 webcasted this semester? I'd like to check the webcasts in the future
Is EECS 126 and EECS 127 overkill for industry? I noticed someone recommended it, but someone else didn't for industry

an argument can be made that ML is just Probability/Stats + a whole lot of Linear Algebra :P 

but like seriously, you will find yourself doing a decent amount of probability if you take 189, and having your fundamentals down through 126 is extremely useful in that case.

first you should the entire machine learning field was based on statistical models, from 50 years ago and to today, which you need extensive probability knowledge to understand. However, cs70 is far from enough.
What is the main purpose of EECS 126 in relation to ML?
Can confirm 202A was useful for the measure theory/functional analysis if you wish to go into theoretical ML research

history.content: Assuming 0 knowledge of Computer Science, Statistics, Machine Learning, and 0 Calculus/LA/DE, what are all the classes a student should take or self study if they want to be employable in ML and/or familiar with the material? In addition, is a masters necessary to get a job in ML, or can a student work on side projects, learn material in these classes, and have a chance?
history.subject: ML Courses Path?
